id="section-block_dbb0074c464485fab9fc0c4065f61c69" class="block-section l-container  l-padding__top--0 l-padding__bottom--0">    <span    class="block-eyebrow  block-eyebrow--center clr-blue-60 l-padding__top--0 l-padding__bottom--micro"    >        <span class="block-eyebrow__text">        Frequently asked questions    </span></span>            <h2 class="block-header block-header--center l-padding__top--0 l-padding__bottom--xx-large block-header--small" style='max-width: 35ch;'   >                <strong>Yes, </strong>you can <strong>deploy Neptune on-premises</strong> and other answers            </h2><div id="accordion-block_3f8cee4a9f9d19e839d21b4ed863ff13" class="block-accordion  l-padding__top--0 l-padding__bottom--xxx-large">            <ul class="block-accordion__list c-wrapper l-grid" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/FAQPage">                                                                                                                        <li class="block-accordion__item c-wrapper__content" itemscope itemprop="mainEntity"                                itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">                                <button class="block-accordion__title header--micro">                                    <span itemprop="name">Can I deploy Neptune on-premises or in a private cloud?</span>                                    <img loading="lazy" decoding="async"                                        src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/image-ratio-holder.svg"                                        data-src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/icon-chevron-down-small.svg"                                        width="24"                                        height="24"                                        class="lazyload"                                        alt="chevron">                                </button>                                                                    <div class="block-accordion__content" itemscope itemprop="acceptedAnswer"                                         itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">                                        <div itemprop="text"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Read more about our <a href="/product/deployment-options">deployment options here</a>. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">But in short, yes, you can deploy Neptune on your on-prem infrastructure or in your private cloud. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It is a set of microservices distributed as a Helm chart that you deploy on Kubernetes. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you don’t have your own Kubernetes cluster deployed, our installer will set up a single-node cluster for you. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As per infrastructure requirements, you need a machine with at least 8 CPUs,  32GB RAM, and 1TB SSD storage.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Read the </span><a href="https://docs.neptune.ai/onprem/intro/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">on-prem documentation</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">if you’re interested, or talk to us (support@neptune.ai) if you have questions.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have any trouble, our deployment engineers will help you all the way.</span></p></div>                                    </div>                                                            </li>                                                                                                                                                        <li class="block-accordion__item c-wrapper__content" itemscope itemprop="mainEntity"                                itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">                                <button class="block-accordion__title header--micro">                                    <span itemprop="name">Can I version datasets without uploading them to Neptune?</span>                                    <img loading="lazy" decoding="async"                                        src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/image-ratio-holder.svg"                                        data-src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/icon-chevron-down-small.svg"                                        width="24"                                        height="24"                                        class="lazyload"                                        alt="chevron">                                </button>                                                                    <div class="block-accordion__content" itemscope itemprop="acceptedAnswer"                                         itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">                                        <div itemprop="text"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yes, you can just reference datasets that sit on your infrastructure or in the cloud. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">For example, you can have your datasets on S3 and just reference the bucket. </span></p><p>run[“train_dataset”].track_files(“s3://datasets/train.csv”)</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Neptune will save the following metadata about this dataset: </span></p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">version (hash), </span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">location (path), </span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">size, </span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">folder structure, and contents (files)</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Neptune never uploads the dataset, just logs the metadata about it. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can later compare datasets or group experiments by dataset version in the UI. </span></p></div>                                    </div>                                                            </li>                                                                                                                                                        <li class="block-accordion__item c-wrapper__content" itemscope itemprop="mainEntity"                                itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">                                <button class="block-accordion__title header--micro">                                    <span itemprop="name">What is the benefit vs MLflow?</span>                                    <img loading="lazy" decoding="async"                                        src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/image-ratio-holder.svg"                                        data-src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/icon-chevron-down-small.svg"                                        width="24"                                        height="24"                                        class="lazyload"                                        alt="chevron">                                </button>                                                                    <div class="block-accordion__content" itemscope itemprop="acceptedAnswer"                                         itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">                                        <div itemprop="text"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Short version. People choose Neptune when:</span></p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They don’t want to maintain infrastructure (including autoscaling, backups etc.),</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They keep scaling their projects (and get into thousands of runs),</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They collaborate with a team (and want user access, multi-tenant UI etc.).</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">For the long version, read this </span><a href="/vs/mlflow" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">full feature-by-feature comparison.</span></a></p></div>                                    </div>                                                            </li>                                                                                                                                                        <li class="block-accordion__item c-wrapper__content" itemscope itemprop="mainEntity"                                itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">                                <button class="block-accordion__title header--micro">                                    <span itemprop="name">What is the benefit vs WandB?</span>                                    <img loading="lazy" decoding="async"                                        src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/image-ratio-holder.svg"                                        data-src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/icon-chevron-down-small.svg"                                        width="24"                                        height="24"                                        class="lazyload"                                        alt="chevron">                                </button>                                                                    <div class="block-accordion__content" itemscope itemprop="acceptedAnswer"                                         itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">                                        <div itemprop="text"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Short version. People choose Neptune when:</span></p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They want to pay a reasonable price for the experiment tracking solution,</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They want a super flexible tool (customizable logging structure, dashboards, works great with time series ML),</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">They want a component for experiment tracking and model versioning, NOT an end-to-end platform (WandB has HPO, orchestration, model deployment, etc. We integrate with best-in-class tools in the space).</span></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">For the long version, read this </span><a href="/vs/wandb" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">full feature-by-feature comparison. </span></a></p></div>                                    </div>                                                            </li>                                                                                                                                                        <li class="block-accordion__item c-wrapper__content" itemscope itemprop="mainEntity"                                itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">                                <button class="block-accordion__title header--micro">                                    <span itemprop="name">Is Neptune used for model monitoring?</span>                                    <img loading="lazy" decoding="async"                                        src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/image-ratio-holder.svg"                                        data-src="https://neptune.ai/wp-content/themes/neptune/img/icon-chevron-down-small.svg"                                        width="24"                                        height="24"                                        class="lazyload"                                        alt="chevron">                                </button>                                                                    <div class="block-accordion__content" itemscope itemprop="acceptedAnswer"                                         itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">                                        <div itemprop="text"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It depends on what “model monitoring” you mean. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As we talk to teams, it seems that “model monitoring” means six different things to three different people: </span></p><ul><li><b>(1) Monitor model performance in production:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> See if the model performance decays over time, and you should re-train it</span></li><li><b>(2) Monitor model input/output distribution:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> See how the distribution of input data, features, and predictions distribution change over time?</span></li><li><b>(3) Monitor model training and re-training: </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">See learning curves, trained model predictions distribution, or confusion matrix during training and re-training</span></li><li><b>(4) Monitor model evaluation and testing: </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">log metrics, charts, prediction, and other metadata for your automated evaluation or testing pipelines</span></li><li><b>(5) Monitor hardware metrics:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> See how much CPU/GPU or Memory your models use during training and inference</span></li><li><b>(6) Monitor CI/CD pipelines for ML: </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">See the evaluations from your CI/CD pipeline jobs and compare them visually</span></li><li style="list-style-type: none;"></li></ul><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">So when looking at tooling landscape and Neptune:</span></p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Neptune does (3) and (4) really well,</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> but we saw teams use it for (5) and (6)</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Prometheus + Grafana is really good at (5), but people use it for (1) and (2)</span></li><li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WhyLabs or Arize are really good at (1) and (2)</span></li></ul></div>                                    </div>                                                            </li>                                                                                </ul>    </div></section><section id="section-block_dbb0074c464485fab9fc0c4065f61c69" class="block-section l-container  l-padding__top--0 l-padding__bottom--0">    <section
